title: 111_hr5503
content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing Protections for the Injured from Limitations on Liability Act" and includes improvements to recovery under the Death on the High Seas Act. The Death on the High Seas Act is amended to include provisions for survivors, nonpecuniary loss, and fair compensation for pain and suffering. The term 'nonpecuniary loss' is defined as loss of care, comfort, and companionship. The Death on the High Seas Act is amended to include provisions for survivors, nonpecuniary loss, and fair compensation for pain and suffering. Section 30305 and 30306 are amended by adding "or law" after "admiralty". Section 30307 is removed, and the corresponding item in the table of sections is also removed. SEC. 3. IMPROVEMENTS TO RECOVERY UNDER JONES ACT. Amends Title 46, United States Code to include recovery for loss of care, comfort, and companionship for a deceased seaman. Repeals section 30105 and related item in the table of sections. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF LIMITATION OF LIABILITY ACT. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF LIMITATION OF LIABILITY ACT. Amends Chapter 305 of title 46, United States Code by repealing multiple sections and related items. Conforming amendments are made to the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and Title 46. SEC. 5. BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION FOR TORT CLAIMS ARISING FROM OIL INCIDENTS. Bankruptcy protection is provided for tort claims arising from oil incidents under Section 363 of title 11, United States Code. The trustee cannot sell or lease significant property of the estate related to wrongful death, personal injury, or property damage without consent from creditors holding two-thirds in amount and more than one-half in number of all unpaid claims. The court may allow the sale or lease of property if there will be enough assets left in the estate or if the debtor's future income is sufficient to pay all claims in full. Amendments are made to Section 1129(b)(2)(B)(ii) regarding claims under a plan of reorganization in bankruptcy cases. Amendments to bankruptcy laws allow for the sale or lease of significant property if creditors holding two-thirds of certain claims consent. Additionally, restrictions are placed on selling significant property if the debtor is liable for wrongful death, personal injury, or property damage claims. Amendments to bankruptcy laws require creditor consent for the sale or lease of significant property of a debtor's affiliate. The court can approve the sale if creditors holding two-thirds of claims agree or if it ensures that all claims will be paid in full. Effective Date: This Act and its amendments will be in effect upon enactment and will apply to claims arising on or after April 20, 2010, that are pending at that time.
